data.description: Travel into the past to discover the present. Explore the partnership between the Grand Portage Anishinaabe and the North West Company during the North American fur trade. Experience the sights and smells of a bustling depot reconstructed in its historic location. See how it shaped co-management with the NPS today. Follow pathways to the past to imagine a drum echo over Gichigami - Lake Superior.
data.directionsInfo: Traveling northeast or southwest on MN Hwy 61 visitors will see signs alerting the approach to Grand Portage National Monument. A right turn exit lane or left turn from Hwy 61 at the Grand Portage Trading Post will take visitors onto Casino Road. Turn left at the first stop sign from Casino Road to Mile Creek Road. About 3/4 mile on Mile Creek Road, look for the large wooden entrance sign. Turn left up the short hill into the Heritage Center parking lot.

operatingHours.description: The Anishinaabe Oodena (Ojibwe Village), the grounds outside of the palisade, and the Mount Rose and Grand Portage trails are open daily year-round.
operatingHours.name: Trails & Grounds

exceptions.name: Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr.

operatingHours.description: The Heritage Center and Trails are open year-round. The Historic Depot opens for the season Memorial Day weekend in May through Columbus Day in mid-October. Winter Hours start 10/14/2025: 9 am - 4:30 pm. Beginning 10/26/2025: closed Sundays.
operatingHours.name: Heritage Center

operatingHours.description: The Historic Site is open from Memorial Day weekend, holidays included, through Columbus Day, and closed the rest of the year.
operatingHours.name: Historic Depot

images.caption: Experience fur trade history on the shore of Lake Superior.

images.caption: The Depot is closed in winter and the Heritage Center and trails are open.

images.title: Ojibwe Village (Anishinaabe Odena)

images.caption: The Ojibwe Village is located in the Historic Depot

images.caption: Colorful blossoms in the Three Sister's Garden

images.caption: Fall is a great time to hike to the mount Rose overlook.

data.weatherInfo: Short, warm summers and long, cold winters define the climate of northern Minnesota. Average range of summer temperature is from 55°F to 78°F in July and average range of winter temperatures is from –11°F to 12°F in January. Average annual precipitation in Grand Portage, MN is about 32 inches.
data.name: Grand Portage

data.description: In the middle of a bustling urban setting, this 72 mile river park offers quiet stretches for fishing, boating and canoeing, birdwatching, bicycling, and hiking. And there are plenty of visitor centers and trails that highlight the fascinating human history of the Mississippi River. This a great place to start your exploration of this important river.

emailAddresses.description: This is the e-mail address for all Park-related questions. This account is checked daily with responses sent out within two days.

data.directionsInfo: Limited metered street parking is available on nearby streets near park headquarters. Several parking ramps are available nearby including the Kellogg Square parking ramp. The Mississippi River Visitor Center is located in the lobby of the Science Museum of Minnesota (120 Kellogg Blvd West, St. Paul, MN).

operatingHours.description: We are a partnership park that overlaps many parks (regional, city, state), other public lands, museums, and historical sites. Check with the specific park site you plan on visiting for their hours. See http://www.nps.gov/miss/planyourvisit/placestogo.htm for more information. The National Park Service does not control the visiting hours for the partner sites. Coldwater Spring (NPS) is open from 6:00 a.m. through 10:00 p.m., 365 days a year.
operatingHours.name: Mississippi National River and Recreation Area

operatingHours.description: Coldwater Spring is open from 6 am to 10 pm daily, 365 days per year.
operatingHours.name: Coldwater Spring (NPS)

images.caption: The park often uses big, safe Voyageur canoes in our programs.

images.caption: Storm clouds begin gathering over Grey Cloud Dunes Scientific and Natural Area

images.title: Fall Colors
images.altText: Trees showing fall colors on their leaves along the river.
images.caption: Vibrant fall colors shown along the river in St. Paul, Minnesota.

images.title: Clouds Over the Mississippi River
images.altText: White clouds streak the blue sky over a river flanked by sandy shorelines and green trees.
images.caption: The upper stretch of the Mississippi River in the Mississippi National River and Recreation Area is often referred to as the "Prairie River" due to its gentle banks. Further downstream is the Mississippi River gorge and below that is the floodplain river

data.weatherInfo: Minnesota has a continental climate characterized by cold winters and warm summers. Spring brings moderate temperatures and low humidity. Summer days may reach temperatures of more than 100°F (38°C), but are usually pleasant with temperatures in the low to mid-80°F (25-30°C). Autumn brings dry, warm days, cool nights and gorgeous fall colors. Winter daytime highs are around 25°F (-3°C). Rarely, winter daytime high temperatures may not get above -10°F (-23°C), sometimes with strong winds.
data.name: Mississippi

data.description: Come to the North Country. Trek the hills and valleys. Stand on the shores of lakes & streams from glaciers 10,000 years before. Clear-flowing water, red/gold of autumn, a fairyland of snow, open prairies, and distant horizons paint the land. Historic sites along the way tell how America settled and grew as a nation. From North Dakota to Vermont, adventure is never far away.
data.directionsInfo: There are numerous trailheads to access the trail. Find North Country Trail Association's Maps and Trails Data to help you get there at https://northcountrytrail.org/trail/maps.

operatingHours.description: The North Country Trail is generally open at all times and during all seasons. There may be area or seasonal closures at the discretion of the local land owner or manager. Please contact local managers or the North Country Trail Association at (616) 897-5987 x1 for the latest trail closures.
operatingHours.name: Trail Hours

images.title: Hiking the North Country Trail
images.altText: Hiking on trail
images.caption: The trail links scenic, natural, historic, and cultural areas across seven states allowing visitors to experience a variety of northern landscapes.

images.title: Fall foliage
images.altText: Fall colors along the trail
images.caption: Enjoy the seasonal changes along the North Country Trail

images.title: Hiking the NCT
images.altText: Hiking on the North Country Trail
images.caption: A variety of landscapes are present along the North Country Trail.

images.title: Trail sign
images.altText: North Country trail sign
images.caption: Trail sign

images.title: North Country National Scenic Trail Trailhead
images.altText: Bulletin board at a trailhead in a forest that features a map and brochures.
images.caption: North Country National Scenic Trail Trailhead in the Chippewa National Forest, Minnesota.

data.weatherInfo: With the trail going through more than 4,800 miles through eight states from the Northeast to the Great Plains, weather along the trail can be highly variable. You could be subject to any kind of weather or temperature related emergency depending on your location and the season. Be careful to protect yourself from heat-related illnesses and hypothermia while out on the trail. Be mindful of lightning, severe storms, and other environmental hazards common to the “North Country.”
data.name: North Country

data.description: For over 3,000 years, Indigenous people have quarried the red stone at this site to make pipes used in prayer and ceremony - a tradition that continues to this day and makes this site sacred to many people.
data.directionsInfo: Plane: Commercial service - located at Sioux Falls, SD -Joe Foss Field airport. 50 miles from Pipestone National Monument. Rental cars are available at the airport. Non-Commercial service - located at Pipestone MN airport. Courtesy car or transit service available to Pipestone National Monument from the airport. Car: Pipestone National Monument is easily accessible from local highways. When you reach the city of Pipestone, road signs will lead you to Pipestone National Monument.

operatingHours.description: The grounds are open 24 hours a day year-round so that visitors may walk the 3/4-mile Circle Trail at any time.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

data.weatherInfo: Weather varies seasonally from warm and humid in the summer to cold and snowy in the winter. Visitors should be prepared for seasonal weather and for rapidly-changing conditions.
data.name: Pipestone

data.description: Grab your paddle and your longing for adventure and head to the St. Croix and Namekagon rivers! Together they form the St. Croix National Scenic Riverway, offering over 200 miles of clean water that glides and rushes through a forested landscape. Paddle, boat, fish, and camp among this wild and scenic beauty. Hiking and historic towns also beckon.
data.directionsInfo: The St. Croix National Scenic Riverway stretches for over 200 miles in northwest Wisconsin and east-central Minnesota. The Namekagon River flows entirely in Wisconsin while the St. Croix River serves as a border between the two states for much of its length. With many different access points there are numerous opportunities for day trips as well as multi-day paddling adventures. Visitor centers are located on the Namekagon River in Trego, Wisconsin, and on the St. Croix River in St. Croix Falls, Wisconsin.

operatingHours.description: The St. Croix and Namekagon rivers are open all-day, year-round except for periods of dangerous water conditions. Access to landings and trails is seasonal.
operatingHours.name: St. Croix National Scenic Riverway

images.title: The St Croix River from Osceola Bluff Autumn
images.altText: A blue river winds through a valley lined with trees in autumn color.
images.caption: One of many beautiful views of the St. Croix River

images.title: Kayaking on the St. Croix River
images.altText: A woman paddles a kayak past cliffs on a forested river.
images.caption: Paddling is an excellent way to experience the St. Croix National Scenic Riverway.

images.title: The St. Croix Dalles
images.altText: Kayakers pass impressive cliffs.
images.caption: The scenic Dalles of the St. Croix River provide dramatic backdrops for paddlers.

images.title: Fast Water on the St. Croix River.
images.altText: A fast river flows over large rocks in a forested landscape.
images.caption: There are opportunities to paddle stretches of fast and slow water on the Riverway.

images.title: Fishing the St. Croix River
images.altText: A man holds a large fish while sitting in a boat near a forested shore.
images.caption: The fishing is spectacular on the St. Croix and Namekagon rivers.

images.title: Evening on the St. Croix River.
images.altText: A man stands next to a river watching a sunset.
images.caption: Watch scenic sunsets from shoreline campsites.

data.weatherInfo: Access to the Riverway is year-round. Early spring temperatures can reach into the 40's resulting in high, fast, and cold water from melting snow and ice. Summers are warm and humid. Severe weather can be experienced anytime from mid-spring through late summer. Fall colors begin in late September with high temperatures averaging in the 60's. Winter can set in early with high temperatures in the teens, lows falling below zero, and occasional heavy snow. The rivers can begin to freeze over by early December.
data.name: Saint Croix

data.description: Voyageurs National Park spans 218,000 acres of lakes, forests, and streams in northern Minnesota. Established in 1975, the park is named after the French-Canadian Voyageurs who once navigated these abundant waters. Voyageurs National Park provides exceptional opportunities for recreation and exploration amidst landscapes rich in natural beauty, history, and cultural heritage.
data.directionsInfo: Voyageurs National Park is located in Northern Minnesota near the Canadian border. Access to Voyageurs is available from many points along Rainy Lake, Kabetogama Lake, Ash River, Crane Lake, and Orr/Pelican Lake. The park's visitor centers and many trails can be reached by car, but much of Voyageurs is best explored by boat. All campsites in the park, except primitive, require a boat to reach.

operatingHours.description: Voyageurs is open 24-hours a day year-round, although activities and services are limited after visitor center hours. Please note that early spring and late fall may present hazards on the lake with thin ice; use caution.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.caption: Experience the Aurora Borealis at Voyageurs National Park

images.caption: For peace and quiet explore the backcountry of the Kabetogama Peninsula

images.title: Sunset in Voyageurs
images.altText: Orange tinted sky with islands scattered throughout the still lake.
images.caption: Enjoy a sunset in Voyageurs National Park.

images.title: Anderson Bay
images.altText: rock cliffs along the lake
images.caption: Explore the unique geology of Voyageurs National Park and see our story unfold.

images.title: Fall Colors
images.altText: orange, yellow, and green colors are showing in the fall foliage
images.caption: The mix of hardwood and conifers create inspiring scenic views especially in the fall.

images.title: Hike a trail
images.altText: A view of a lake peaks through a stand of pine trees.

data.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in Voyageur country. During June, July, and August periods of fine, mild weather prevail. The frost-free season averages 120 days from June to mid-September. The average ice-out date is May 3. The first measurable snowfall occurs in late October and the last in late April or early May.
data.name: Voyageurs
